title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Monday, July 14, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. Gazette Classification: Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Houghton Library Cost: Free More info: library.harvard.edu…

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Monday, July 14, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Monday, July 14, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Monday, July 14, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. Gazette Classification: Community, Diversity and Inclusion, Education, Ethics, Exhibitions, Humanities, Science, Special Events Organization/Sponsor: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments Cost: Free Contact Info: See museum website for additional gallery closures. title: Edvard Munch: Technically Speaking
location: Harvard Art Museums32 Quincy St. Cambridge Tuesday, July 15, 2025 Discover the experimental methods of Edvard Munch, who creatively explored materials and techniques across media.A dynamic collaboration between curatorial and conservation experts at the Harvard Art Museums, Edvard Munch: Technically Speaking offers rare insight into the Norwegian artist’s innovative techniques and the recurring themes across his paintings, woodcuts, lithographs, etchings, and combination prints. The Harvard Art Museums house one of the largest and most significant collections of artwork by Munch in the United States, and the exhibition showcases roughly 70 works, including key loans from Munchmuseet, Oslo. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Wednesday, July 16, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. Gazette Classification: Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Houghton Library Cost: Free More info: library.harvard.edu…

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Wednesday, July 16, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Wednesday, July 16, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Wednesday, July 16, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: Accountability and Social Media Engagement of Charitable Organizations in Ukraine during the War
location: CGIS-Knafel/North Building2nd Floor, Room K-2621737 Cambridge St. Cambridge Wednesday, July 16, 2025, 5 – 6:30pm This talk examines the landscape of accountability in Ukrainian charitable organizations, with a focus on the impact of social media engagement during times of crisis. In Ukraine, 86% of the population has consistently engaged in charitable activities since 2022. In contrast, 64% of Americans made charitable donations in 2023. This high level of charitable engagement in Ukraine is notable, given the urgent need to fund the military and support those affected by the ongoing war. Social media has been extensively utilized for both charity fundraising and reporting/accountability. There’s a need to understand the dynamic interaction between the charity, its donors, and the broader public, emphasizing the role of dialogic accountability in maintaining transparency and trust. Using the Serhii Prytula Charity Fund as a case study, Dr. Iermolenko will analyze how the emotive power of accounting on social media can help charities foster meaningful conversations, improve decision-making, and ensure effective accountability. Gazette Classification: Lecture Organization/Sponsor: Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute Speaker(s): Olga Iermolenko, Associate Professor, PhD, Nord University Business School, Visiting Scholar at the Weatherhead Center for International Affairs, Harvard University. Harvard Key Required: No More info: www.huri.harvard.edu…

title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Thursday, July 17, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: All Stars: The Sensational History of Athletics as Entertainment
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Friday, July 18, 2025 Prior to the rise of professional sports in the 20th century, boundaries between sport, theater, and spectacle were blurred. This exhibit explores sports as a mode of performance and entertainment. What connects outstanding athletes across time are attributes such as strength, balance, and nerve—themes around which this exhibition is organized. Athletic stars of yesteryear left an extraordinary legacy in the form of prints, photographs, and other ephemera, and these materials underscore how the appeal of modern sports was built on a shared foundation of skilled athleticism and sensational entertainment.This exhibition was co-curated by Matthew Wittmann and Karintha Lowe of the Harvard Theatre Collection. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Friday, July 18, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Friday, July 18, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Sunday, July 20, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Sunday, July 20, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: All Stars: The Sensational History of Athletics as Entertainment
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Monday, July 21, 2025 Prior to the rise of professional sports in the 20th century, boundaries between sport, theater, and spectacle were blurred. This exhibit explores sports as a mode of performance and entertainment. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Monday, July 21, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. Gazette Classification: Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Houghton Library Cost: Free More info: library.harvard.edu…

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Monday, July 21, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Illuminate: Contextualizing Asian American Women’s Stories through the Archives
location: Lia and William Poorvu Gallery, Schlesinger Library3 James St. Cambridge Monday, July 21, 2025, 9am – 4:30pm "Illuminate: Contextualizing Asian American Women’s Stories through the Archives" spotlights the stories and lives of Asian American women whose collections are held in the Schlesinger Library. The featured materials provide viewers an opportunity to think critically and contextualize the often invisible and forgotten histories of Asian and Asian American women in the United States. At the same time, the exhibition examines how race, ethnicity, gender, citizenship, and migration impact the collective memory of a nation through primary sources. title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Tuesday, July 22, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Tuesday, July 22, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Tuesday, July 22, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: All Stars: The Sensational History of Athletics as Entertainment
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Wednesday, July 23, 2025 Prior to the rise of professional sports in the 20th century, boundaries between sport, theater, and spectacle were blurred. This exhibit explores sports as a mode of performance and entertainment. What connects outstanding athletes across time are attributes such as strength, balance, and nerve—themes around which this exhibition is organized. Athletic stars of yesteryear left an extraordinary legacy in the form of prints, photographs, and other ephemera, and these materials underscore how the appeal of modern sports was built on a shared foundation of skilled athleticism and sensational entertainment.This exhibition was co-curated by Matthew Wittmann and Karintha Lowe of the Harvard Theatre Collection. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Wednesday, July 23, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. Gazette Classification: Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Houghton Library Cost: Free More info: library.harvard.edu…

title: When Soft Power Turns Hard: Cancel-Culture Controversy During the Russian-Ukrainian War
location: CGIS-Knafel/North Building, 2nd Floor, Room K-2621737 Cambridge St.Cambridge Wednesday, July 23, 2025, 5 – 6:30pm Russian aggression against Ukraine evoked nearly universal international condemnation but got much less unanimous response in more practical terms of political, economic, and other sanctions. Many countries refused to introduce any measures against the aggressor state. Culture appeared to be the most controversial field, where even the Western democracies, rather unanimous in their response to the Russian assault, failed to achieve any consensus on suitable measures and policies vis-à-vis the rogue state. While virtually nobody questions the need of sanctions against the specific persons and institutions that support the war, the wholesale rejection of Russian culture and cancelling of its iconic figures is often vehemently denied. The lecture will delve into the essence of these debates, trying to answer a fundamental question: To what degree and in which way a seemingly innocent, apolitical cultural ‘soft power’ contributes to the militant ‘hard power’ of the aggressor state during the war. Gazette Classification: Lecture Organization/Sponsor: Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute Speaker(s): Mykola Riabchuk, Senior Research Fellow at the Institute of Political and Ethnic Studies in Kyiv, Visiting researcher at the George Washington University Harvard Key Required: No More info: www.huri.harvard.edu…

title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Thursday, July 24, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Thursday, July 24, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Thursday, July 24, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Thursday, July 24, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Saturday, July 26, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: All Stars: The Sensational History of Athletics as Entertainment
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Monday, July 28, 2025 Prior to the rise of professional sports in the 20th century, boundaries between sport, theater, and spectacle were blurred. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Monday, July 28, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. Gazette Classification: Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Houghton Library Cost: Free More info: library.harvard.edu…

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Monday, July 28, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Tuesday, July 29, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Tuesday, July 29, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Tuesday, July 29, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: Displacement, Emplacement, and Reintegration: IDP Experiences, 2014-2021
location: CGIS-Knafel/North Building, 2nd Floor, Room K-2621737 Cambridge St.Cambridge Wednesday, July 30, 2025, 5 – 6:30pm This lecture explores the question of how anthropologists must navigate the context of war to continue to do research. Dr. Emily Channell-Justice will describe the process of developing her current research on internal displacement in Ukraine since 2014, which was then disrupted by the full-scale invasion. She will discuss data sources and pose questions about ethical research during ongoing hostilities. The lecture will also explore the possibilities of collaborative work that may strengthen the research process and improve its conclusions. The discussion will focus on the main data set: 80 interviews with internally displaced Ukrainians from Donetsk and Luhansk regions and Crimea, collected by a Ukrainian anthropologist between 2014 and 2016 and given to Dr. Channell-Justice to use for research. Dr. Channell-Justice will describe what these interviews reveal about the experience of displacement and doing research when circumstances do not allow for normal ethnographic data collection through long-term participant observation. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Thursday, July 31, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Thursday, July 31, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Thursday, July 31, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Saturday, August 2, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Monday, August 4, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. Gazette Classification: Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Houghton Library Cost: Free More info: library.harvard.edu…

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Monday, August 4, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Tuesday, August 5, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Tuesday, August 5, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Thursday, August 7, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Thursday, August 7, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Thursday, August 7, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: All Stars: The Sensational History of Athletics as Entertainment
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Friday, August 8, 2025 Prior to the rise of professional sports in the 20th century, boundaries between sport, theater, and spectacle were blurred. This exhibit explores sports as a mode of performance and entertainment. What connects outstanding athletes across time are attributes such as strength, balance, and nerve—themes around which this exhibition is organized. Athletic stars of yesteryear left an extraordinary legacy in the form of prints, photographs, and other ephemera, and these materials underscore how the appeal of modern sports was built on a shared foundation of skilled athleticism and sensational entertainment.This exhibition was co-curated by Matthew Wittmann and Karintha Lowe of the Harvard Theatre Collection. title: The Caribbean: Sea of Resilience
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Friday, August 8, 2025 "The Caribbean: Sea of Resilience" sheds light on Houghton’s holdings of Caribbean materials and the creativity, strength, and history of the Caribbean people. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Monday, August 11, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Monday, August 11, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Wednesday, August 13, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Wednesday, August 13, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Friday, August 15, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Friday, August 15, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Friday, August 15, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: The Caribbean: Sea of Resilience
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Monday, August 18, 2025 "The Caribbean: Sea of Resilience" sheds light on Houghton’s holdings of Caribbean materials and the creativity, strength, and history of the Caribbean people. It seeks to honor creators whose art and thought enrich our collection, while bringing to light the stories of those whose voices were long overshadowed by colonial histories. A variety of Caribbean materials can be found at Houghton, ranging from an early map of the region, a document signed by Toussaint L'Ouverture, and a manuscript by renowned Antiguan-American author Jamaica Kincaid. This exhibition was guest curated by Chloe McKain, Class of 2027 and President of the Harvard Caribbean Club. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Monday, August 18, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Tuesday, August 19, 2025 "The Caribbean: Sea of Resilience" sheds light on Houghton’s holdings of Caribbean materials and the creativity, strength, and history of the Caribbean people. title: The Punched Card from the Industrial Revolution to the Information Age
location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Tuesday, August 19, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. Gazette Classification: Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Houghton Library Cost: Free More info: library.harvard.edu…

title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Tuesday, August 19, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. Gazette Classification: Art/Design, Exhibitions Organization/Sponsor: Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies Speaker(s): Farrah Karapetian, Artist; Associate Professor, University of San Diego Cost: Free Contact Info: laura_sargent@fas.harvard.edu More info: daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu…

title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Tuesday, August 19, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Thursday, August 21, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Thursday, August 21, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Monday, August 25, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. title: Castaway: The Afterlife of Plastic
location: Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology11 Divinity AveCambridge Monday, August 25, 2025, 9am – 5pm In this exhibition, the art collective TRES invites us to share their 2016 journey to document, collect, and photograph debris along the beaches of Australia. Evoking archaeology, marine biology, and cartography, their images summon us to more deeply engage with the natural vistas and objects they have encountered, and to examine and interpret them with fresh perspectives.TRES transports us with photographs of glowing orbs that resemble celestial spheres more than the bottle caps they once were. Making their way as garbage to Australia from as far away as China, these objects have been scarred by Bryozoa, tiny micro-organisms which can be seen in the display case in this exhibition. Now, plastic items such as these lay scattered about the otherwise pristine-appearing landscapes.The rhythmic flow of images challenges us to make sense of the terrain. With hand-drawn maps and charts, TRES attempts to bring order to a perplexing world, where plastic objects resemble organic ones, and “natural” landscapes bear unmistakable traces of human-made pollution. title: Measuring Difference
location: Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments1 Oxford St.Cambridge Monday, August 25, 2025, 11am – 4pm Today, measurement is everywhere. We understand everything around us in inches, degrees, gallons, decibels, and more. But measurements are human inventions. It is through measures that we learn to see difference, to compare the world.In the Americas, colonial powers introduced new measurements to describe and exploit the “New World.” Existing ways of understanding and explaining the world and our relationship to others were displaced, cementing European measures as norms and tools of authority. Using examples from across the Americas, this exhibit illustrates what—and who—was measured, and how. location: Houghton LibraryHarvard YardCambridge Thursday, August 28, 2025 2025 marks the 300th anniversary of a technology associated with the computer age, but with roots in the Industrial Revolution. In 1725, French silk weaver Basile Bouchon invented the use of a paper tape with punched holes to automate the work of a loom. By the 19th century, punchcard-controlled looms produced sophisticated textiles, including fabric "pages" woven from silk to simulate the leaves of a medieval manuscript. Computing pioneer Charles Babbage first envisioned adapting punched cards to computing; in the early computer age, they were the primary means for data entry and processing. In "Punched Card Methods in Scientific Computation," Wallace Eckert shared his work using punched cards to perform complex calculations such as determining the orbits of planets. title: “The Things They Shared” Art Exhibition
location: CGIS South, 3rd floor1730 Cambridge St.Cambridge Thursday, August 28, 2025, 7am – 7pm “The Things They Shared” is an excerpt from Farrah Karapetian’s ongoing project, “Fieldwork.” It delves into the lives of cotton field workers in Uzbekistan, exploring their relationships with community, governance, subordination, personal freedom, and the natural and social environments they navigate. It also responds to representational histories — miming anthropological typology and the documentary photograph but privileging the personal experience of the worker rather than institutional narratives. Karapetian’s artistic approach is as integral to her message as is the subject matter itself. Cyanotype is one of photography’s original processes and requires only sun and water for its exposure and development, a priority in the context of industrially irrigated cotton fields that impact water ecologies. She uses a spray gun to deploy the cyanotype emulsion onto cotton rag substrate so as to clarify her voice, rather than purport to be objective. The cyanotype technique allows her to infuse softness into her photographic collages, creating layered, abstract images that speak directly to the essence of her subjects: cotton, the field, water, the sun, and the human touch. title: Sea Monsters: Wonders of Nature and Imagination
location: Harvard Museum of Natural History26 Oxford St.Cambridge Ongoing through Friday, June 26, 2026, 5pm Embark on a daring voyage into the depths of human imagination at the Harvard Museum of Natural History’s new exhibition, Sea Monsters: Wonders of Nature and Imagination. Featuring ancient mariners' maps, literature, works of art, and natural history specimens, this exhibit explores the allure of serpents, krakens, and other monsters of the deep. Peer into the minds of scholars from centuries past, and study sea creatures whose real lives are often more astonishing than the fantastical beings we might have imagined. Dive into the ocean of human consciousness, where dreams and fears entwine with reality, offering profound insights into our world and ourselves. Join us in unraveling the mysteries of the deep sea and the human psyche, where sea monsters—both real and imagined—beckon us to explore the unknown. Additional Session Added!!  
 
Do you want to make significant progress to your prospectus, dissertation, or other research or writing project this summer? With a wide-open schedule and reduced social support, how can you be sure you will get down to work each day? Easy! Register for Productivity to PhD, set a goal, and join us for two weeks of daily jump starts!
An academic coach and a small group of doctoral students will meet every weekday morning for shared structure, accountability, and encouragement. At each session, after a brief check-in to review the prior day’s progress and set goals for the work hour, each student will work independently on- or off-line for 60 minutes. Upon registration, you will receive an email with Zoom links for each day.
 
Daily attendance is suggested for group accountability. Open to all Harvard Griffin GSAS students.

title: Youth in Public Health Symposium, Dongguan 2025
dateTime: Monday, August 4 2025 at 9:00 AM EDT to Friday, August 8 2025 at 5:00 PM EDT Add To Google Calendar | iCal/Outlook
location: Tsinglan School: https://www.tsinglan.cn/en/index
description:
ABOUT YPHS
The Youth in Public Health Symposium (YPHS) was established in 2016 by Dr. Liming Liang, a Professor of Statistical Genetics in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics. The symposium aims to expose high school students to different fields of public health and provide practical examples of the knowledge they learn in science classes. This helps students learn how rigorous research is done in public health and make informed decisions about their future college majors. YPHS incorporates nano-courses that allow students to connect with leading researchers, acquire fundamental knowledge, and develop community projects in public health areas. For the symposiums from previous years, please click on the links (2024 Dongguan Camp, 2024 Boston Camp, 2023 Shanghai Camp, 2023 Boston Camp, 2020 Online Forum, 2019 Boston Camp, 2018 Boston Camp).
 
ABOUT THE DONGGUAN 2025 PROGRAM
This summer school in Dongguan, Guangdong Province, China, is part of the YPHS programs designed specifically for high school students. The event will be held from August 4th to 8th, 2025, at Tsinglan School.
As a non-profit initiative, this program offers participants the opportunity to:
- Engage with world-class scholars: Work closely with Harvard University professors and current doctoral students to explore cutting-edge topics in public health and learn about academic and career pathways in the field.
- Collaborate with talented peers: Join a community of outstanding high school students to conduct group-based, project-style research, delve into public health knowledge, and enjoy the excitement of scientific inquiry.
- Apply knowledge to real-world challenges: Investigate public health issues, and use scientific knowledge to create meaningful solutions, shaping yourself into a future leader in public health.
- Receive formal recognition: Earn a certificate of completion issued by a Harvard University professor.
- Expand your global experience: Outstanding participants may be invited to the Youth in Public Health Symposium in Boston in Spring 2026.
 
Program Highlights
- Pre-program preparation: Students will receive curated reading and preparatory materials in June 2025, designed by the Harvard team.
- Core and elective courses: A flexible course system combining essential public health topics and personalized electives, allowing students to tailor their learning experience.
- Research and presentations: Under the guidance of Harvard doctoral students, participants will apply their knowledge to address pressing public health challenges, culminating in research proposals, oral presentations, and academic poster displays.
 
Recruitment Details
- Enrollment: 100 students
- Eligibility: Students entering grades 9–12 in the 2025–2026 academic year with a strong academic foundation, a keen interest in public health, and proficiency in English.
- Application: Students are required to submit an application form. More details and specific requirements can be found at here.
